history.content:
The real question is why would you want to do something like this. If you're thinking just for helpfulness in job interviews, definitely don't do this; it won't be worth it.

Now in terms of answering your question, it depends on your experience. If you've had significant programming experience (more specifically, if the material in 61B seems like something you already know thoroughly), then you could attempt taking 170. You might say that there is no programming at all in 170, but it is the CS/algorithmic way of thinking that you need, which can only come from experience.

Moreover, 61B directly prepares you for 170 through the concepts on graph theory, data structures and even dynamic programming (introduced just this previous semester). One possible shortcoming is that Prof. Hilfinger tends to focus less on these things than Prof. Hug.

There is a reason there are prereqs in place. Even though they are not enforced, they are put in place by the faculty to ensure that students are adequately prepared for a course. I am sorry if I come off as arrogant but I'm just trying to make it clear that this is strongly not advisable, and the fact that you're even questioning this tells me that you shouldn't do it.

=================================

As somebody who took 61B and 170 together as a freshman, it is indeed feasible to take both together (and do well). I wouldn't worry about needing 170 concepts for interviews - 61B does prepare you well. I would only recommend that you do so if you're completely and entirely confident that 61B will be easy, perhaps even trivial for you - to do otherwise would be attempting to run before one can walk. 170 is essentially 61B, but with 70-style proofs.

The real question is why would you want to do something like this. If you're thinking just for helpfulness in job interviews, definitely don't do this; it won't be worth it.

Now in terms of answering your question, it depends on your experience. If you've had significant programming experience (more specifically, if the material in 61B seems like something you already know thoroughly), then you could attempt taking 170. You might say that there is no programming at all in 170, but it is the CS/algorithmic way of thinking that you need, which can only come from experience.

Moreover, 61B directly prepares you for 170 through the concepts on graph theory, data structures and even dynamic programming (introduced just this previous semester). One possible shortcoming is that Prof. Hilfinger tends to focus less on these things than Prof. Hug.

There is a reason there are prereqs in place. Even though they are not enforced, they are put in place by the faculty to ensure that students are adequately prepared for a course. I am sorry if I come off as arrogant but I'm just trying to make it clear that this is strongly not advisable, and the fact that you're even questioning this tells me that you shouldn't do it.

children.subject: I am skeptic about why you would want to do this. I feel that courses should be taken when you are prepared to take them and you shouldn't feel a need to rush unless spring is your last semester or something. You miss out of all the benefits if you are constantly struggling in a class. This is fine if the class is hard, but totally not ok if it is because you did not take a pre-requisite ahead and have the time to do it. Even if you declare by the end of sophomore year you should be in track to graduate in time and still experiment a lot (unless you want to take every single class in the CS department which would not be the best idea in the world either). Just my two cents, take 61b, take 70 and then take 170. I am sure that 61b + 70 and then 170 will require you to put in less work than taking 170 + 61b and you will not be trying to learn a whole semester every time you run into a new topic you have no clue about

history.content:
How feasible is it to take both 61b and 170 together (having obviously already taken 61a and 70)?

I know 61b and 70 are both essential pre-requirements to success in 170 but I was curious to know if a little extra effort would be enough to reap the benefits of taking both 61b and 170 together--benefits being the reinforcing overlap of concepts.

Also might be important to note the professors this Fall are for 61b Hilfinger, 170 Rao and Chiesa
history.subject: Concurrent enrollment 170 and 61b
